title: Data Blinding with vazul
text: vazul package provides functions data blinding research contexts. Data blinding helps prevent researcher bias anonymizing data preserving analytical validity. vignette introduces main functions demonstrates usage practical examples. two primary approaches data blinding: Masking: Replaces original values anonymous labels, completely hiding original information. Scrambling: Randomizes order existing values preserving original data content. approach available three levels: Vector level: mask_labels() scramble_values() - operate single vectors Data frame level: mask_variables() scramble_variables() - operate columns data frame Row-wise level: mask_variables_rowwise() scramble_variables_rowwise() - operate within rows across columns
code: library(vazul) library(dplyr)

title: Data Blinding with vazul
text: Masking functions replace categorical values anonymous labels. useful want completely hide original information, treatment conditions group assignments. mask_labels() function takes character factor vector replaces unique value randomly assigned masked label. x: character factor vector mask prefix: Character string use prefix masked labels (default: "masked_group_") Notice : unique value receives unique masked label original value always maps masked label assignment masked labels original values randomized can customize prefix used masked labels: function preserves factor structure input factor: Let’s use williams dataset mask ecology condition: Now researchers can analyze data without knowing condition “Desperate” vs “Hopeful”. mask_variables() function applies masking multiple columns data frame simultaneously. data: data frame ...: Columns mask (supports tidyselect helpers) across_variables: TRUE, selected variables share masked labels; FALSE (default), variable gets independent masked labels default, column gets set masked labels column name prefix: Notice column now prefix (treatment_group_, outcome_group_). across_variables = TRUE, selected columns share mapping: shared masking, value “” maps label columns. can use tidyselect helpers select columns: mask_variables_rowwise() function applies consistent masking within row across multiple columns. useful repeated measures matched conditions. data: data frame ...: Column sets mask (supports tidyselect helpers) prefix: Character string use prefix masked labels (default: "masked_group_") Within row, original values consistently mapped masked labels, mapping independent across rows.
code: # Create a simple treatment vector treatment <- c("control", "treatment", "control", "treatment", "control")  # Mask the labels set.seed(123) masked_treatment <- mask_labels(treatment) masked_treatment #>           control         treatment           control         treatment  #> "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02" "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02"  #>           control  #> "masked_group_01" set.seed(456) mask_labels(treatment, prefix = "group_") #>    control  treatment    control  treatment    control  #> "group_01" "group_02" "group_01" "group_02" "group_01" set.seed(789) mask_labels(treatment, prefix = "condition_") #>        control      treatment        control      treatment        control  #> "condition_01" "condition_02" "condition_01" "condition_02" "condition_01" # Create a factor vector ecology <- factor(c("Desperate", "Hopeful", "Desperate", "Hopeful"))  set.seed(123) masked_ecology <- mask_labels(ecology) masked_ecology #>       Desperate         Hopeful       Desperate         Hopeful  #> masked_group_01 masked_group_02 masked_group_01 masked_group_02  #> Levels: masked_group_01 masked_group_02 class(masked_ecology) #> [1] "factor" data(williams)  set.seed(42) williams$ecology_masked <- mask_labels(williams$ecology)  # Compare original and masked values head(williams[c("subject", "ecology", "ecology_masked")], 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    subject        ecology   ecology_masked  #>    <chr>          <chr>     <chr>           #>  1 A30MP4LXV4MIFD Hopeful   masked_group_01 #>  2 A16X5FB3HAFCKN Desperate masked_group_02 #>  3 A1E9D1OT9VJYDZ Desperate masked_group_02 #>  4 A16FPOYD7566WI Hopeful   masked_group_01 #>  5 A11NOTVHWST7Y3 Desperate masked_group_02 #>  6 A3TDR6MXS6UO5Z Desperate masked_group_02 #>  7 A3OD4F0SA7EBCL Desperate masked_group_02 #>  8 A123PBQDU71I5O Hopeful   masked_group_01 #>  9 A25NGIY591U3DK Hopeful   masked_group_01 #> 10 A11WCFPJSR5VZP Desperate masked_group_02 df <- data.frame(   treatment = c("control", "intervention", "control", "intervention"),   outcome = c("success", "failure", "success", "failure"),   score = c(85, 92, 78, 88) )  set.seed(123) result <- mask_variables(df, c("treatment", "outcome")) result #>            treatment          outcome score #> 1 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01    85 #> 2 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_02    92 #> 3 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01    78 #> 4 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_02    88 df2 <- data.frame(   pre_condition = c("A", "B", "C", "A"),   post_condition = c("B", "A", "A", "C"),   score = c(1, 2, 3, 4) )  set.seed(456) result_shared <- mask_variables(df2, c("pre_condition", "post_condition"),                                 across_variables = TRUE) result_shared #>     pre_condition  post_condition score #> 1 masked_group_01 masked_group_03     1 #> 2 masked_group_03 masked_group_01     2 #> 3 masked_group_02 masked_group_01     3 #> 4 masked_group_01 masked_group_02     4 set.seed(789) mask_variables(df, where(is.character)) #>            treatment          outcome score #> 1 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_02    85 #> 2 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_01    92 #> 3 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_02    78 #> 4 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_01    88 df <- data.frame(   treat_1 = c("control", "treatment", "placebo"),   treat_2 = c("treatment", "placebo", "control"),   treat_3 = c("placebo", "control", "treatment"),   id = 1:3 )  set.seed(123) result <- mask_variables_rowwise(df, starts_with("treat_")) result #>           treat_1         treat_2         treat_3 id #> 1 masked_group_03 masked_group_01 masked_group_02  1 #> 2 masked_group_01 masked_group_02 masked_group_03  2 #> 3 masked_group_02 masked_group_03 masked_group_01  3

title: Data Blinding with vazul
text: mask_variables() function applies masking multiple columns data frame simultaneously. data: data frame ...: Columns mask (supports tidyselect helpers) across_variables: TRUE, selected variables share masked labels; FALSE (default), variable gets independent masked labels default, column gets set masked labels column name prefix: Notice column now prefix (treatment_group_, outcome_group_). across_variables = TRUE, selected columns share mapping: shared masking, value “” maps label columns. can use tidyselect helpers select columns:
code: df <- data.frame(   treatment = c("control", "intervention", "control", "intervention"),   outcome = c("success", "failure", "success", "failure"),   score = c(85, 92, 78, 88) )  set.seed(123) result <- mask_variables(df, c("treatment", "outcome")) result #>            treatment          outcome score #> 1 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01    85 #> 2 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_02    92 #> 3 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01    78 #> 4 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_02    88 df2 <- data.frame(   pre_condition = c("A", "B", "C", "A"),   post_condition = c("B", "A", "A", "C"),   score = c(1, 2, 3, 4) )  set.seed(456) result_shared <- mask_variables(df2, c("pre_condition", "post_condition"),                                 across_variables = TRUE) result_shared #>     pre_condition  post_condition score #> 1 masked_group_01 masked_group_03     1 #> 2 masked_group_03 masked_group_01     2 #> 3 masked_group_02 masked_group_01     3 #> 4 masked_group_01 masked_group_02     4 set.seed(789) mask_variables(df, where(is.character)) #>            treatment          outcome score #> 1 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_02    85 #> 2 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_01    92 #> 3 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_02    78 #> 4 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_01    88

title: Data Blinding with vazul
text: Scrambling functions randomize order values preserving original data content. approach maintains data distribution breaking connection observations original values. scramble_values() function randomly reorders elements vector. x: vector scramble Scrambling preserves: original values (nothing lost changed) data type distribution values scramble_variables() function scrambles values specified columns data frame. data: data frame cols: Columns scramble (supports tidyselect helpers) together: TRUE, variables scrambled together unit per row; FALSE (default), variable scrambled independently .groups: Optional grouping columns within-group scrambling column scrambled independently: Notice x y scrambled independently . together = TRUE, selected columns scrambled unit, preserving row-level relationships: Notice pairs (1, “”), (2, “b”), etc., remain intact assigned different rows. Use .groups parameter scramble within groups: Values x swapped within original group (B). can combine parameters: scramble_variables_rowwise() function scrambles values within row across specified columns. useful scrambling repeated measures item responses. data: data frame ...: Column sets scramble (supports tidyselect helpers) Within row, values shuffled among item columns. can scramble multiple sets columns independently:
code: # Numeric data set.seed(123) numbers <- 1:10 scramble_values(numbers) #>  [1]  3 10  2  8  6  9  1  7  5  4 # Character data set.seed(456) letters_vec <- letters[1:5] scramble_values(letters_vec) #> [1] "e" "a" "c" "b" "d" # Factor data set.seed(789) conditions <- factor(c("A", "B", "C", "A", "B")) scramble_values(conditions) #> [1] B A B C A #> Levels: A B C set.seed(100) original <- c(1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4, 4, 4) scrambled <- scramble_values(original)  # Same values, different order sort(original) == sort(scrambled) #>  [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE  # Same frequency distribution table(original) #> original #> 1 2 3 4  #> 1 2 3 4 table(scrambled) #> scrambled #> 1 2 3 4  #> 1 2 3 4 data(williams)  set.seed(42) williams$age_scrambled <- scramble_values(williams$age)  # The values are the same, just reordered summary(williams$age) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   21.00   26.00   32.00   34.04   38.00   71.00 summary(williams$age_scrambled) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   21.00   26.00   32.00   34.04   38.00   71.00  # But individual correspondences are broken head(williams[c("subject", "age", "age_scrambled")], 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    subject          age age_scrambled #>    <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl> #>  1 A30MP4LXV4MIFD    34            25 #>  2 A16X5FB3HAFCKN    30            26 #>  3 A1E9D1OT9VJYDZ    40            25 #>  4 A16FPOYD7566WI    35            38 #>  5 A11NOTVHWST7Y3    26            25 #>  6 A3TDR6MXS6UO5Z    33            28 #>  7 A3OD4F0SA7EBCL    33            57 #>  8 A123PBQDU71I5O    30            32 #>  9 A25NGIY591U3DK    48            25 #> 10 A11WCFPJSR5VZP    33            43 df <- data.frame(   x = 1:6,   y = letters[1:6],   group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B") )  set.seed(123) scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y")) #>   x y group #> 1 3 e     A #> 2 6 d     A #> 3 2 b     A #> 4 4 f     B #> 5 5 a     B #> 6 1 c     B set.seed(456) scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y"), together = TRUE) #>   x y group #> 1 5 e     A #> 2 6 f     A #> 3 3 c     A #> 4 2 b     B #> 5 1 a     B #> 6 4 d     B set.seed(1) scramble_variables(df, "x", .groups = "group") #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     1 a     A     #> 2     2 b     A     #> 3     3 c     A     #> 4     4 d     B     #> 5     5 e     B     #> 6     6 f     B set.seed(100) scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y"), .groups = "group", together = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     2 b     A     #> 2     1 a     A     #> 3     3 c     A     #> 4     6 f     B     #> 5     4 d     B     #> 6     5 e     B data(williams)  # Scramble age and ecology within gender groups set.seed(42) williams_scrambled <- williams |>   scramble_variables(c("age", "ecology"), .groups = "gender")  # Check that values are preserved within groups williams |>   group_by(gender) |>   summarise(mean_age = mean(age, na.rm = TRUE)) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   gender mean_age #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1      1     33.8 #> 2      2     34.6  williams_scrambled |>   group_by(gender) |>   summarise(mean_age = mean(age, na.rm = TRUE)) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   gender mean_age #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1      1     33.8 #> 2      2     34.6 df <- data.frame(   item1 = c(1, 4, 7),   item2 = c(2, 5, 8),   item3 = c(3, 6, 9),   id = 1:3 )  set.seed(123) result <- scramble_variables_rowwise(df, c("item1", "item2", "item3")) result #>   item1 item2 item3 id #> 1     3     1     2  1 #> 2     5     4     6  2 #> 3     8     9     7  3 df2 <- data.frame(   day_1 = c(1, 4, 7),   day_2 = c(2, 5, 8),   day_3 = c(3, 6, 9),   score_a = c(10, 40, 70),   score_b = c(20, 50, 80),   id = 1:3 )  set.seed(1) result2 <- scramble_variables_rowwise(   df2,   starts_with("day_"),   c("score_a", "score_b") ) result2 #>   day_1 day_2 day_3 score_a score_b id #> 1     1     2     3      20      10  1 #> 2     4     5     6      40      50  2 #> 3     9     7     8      70      80  3

text: scramble_values() function randomly reorders elements vector. x: vector scramble Scrambling preserves: original values (nothing lost changed) data type distribution values
code: # Numeric data set.seed(123) numbers <- 1:10 scramble_values(numbers) #>  [1]  3 10  2  8  6  9  1  7  5  4 # Character data set.seed(456) letters_vec <- letters[1:5] scramble_values(letters_vec) #> [1] "e" "a" "c" "b" "d" # Factor data set.seed(789) conditions <- factor(c("A", "B", "C", "A", "B")) scramble_values(conditions) #> [1] B A B C A #> Levels: A B C set.seed(100) original <- c(1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4, 4, 4) scrambled <- scramble_values(original)  # Same values, different order sort(original) == sort(scrambled) #>  [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE  # Same frequency distribution table(original) #> original #> 1 2 3 4  #> 1 2 3 4 table(scrambled) #> scrambled #> 1 2 3 4  #> 1 2 3 4 data(williams)  set.seed(42) williams$age_scrambled <- scramble_values(williams$age)  # The values are the same, just reordered summary(williams$age) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   21.00   26.00   32.00   34.04   38.00   71.00 summary(williams$age_scrambled) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   21.00   26.00   32.00   34.04   38.00   71.00  # But individual correspondences are broken head(williams[c("subject", "age", "age_scrambled")], 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    subject          age age_scrambled #>    <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl> #>  1 A30MP4LXV4MIFD    34            25 #>  2 A16X5FB3HAFCKN    30            26 #>  3 A1E9D1OT9VJYDZ    40            25 #>  4 A16FPOYD7566WI    35            38 #>  5 A11NOTVHWST7Y3    26            25 #>  6 A3TDR6MXS6UO5Z    33            28 #>  7 A3OD4F0SA7EBCL    33            57 #>  8 A123PBQDU71I5O    30            32 #>  9 A25NGIY591U3DK    48            25 #> 10 A11WCFPJSR5VZP    33            43

Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   21.00   26.00   32.00   34.04   38.00   71.00 summary(williams$age_scrambled) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   21.00   26.00   32.00   34.04   38.00   71.00  # But individual correspondences are broken head(williams[c("subject", "age", "age_scrambled")], 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 3 #>    subject          age age_scrambled #>    <chr>          <dbl>         <dbl> #>  1 A30MP4LXV4MIFD    34            25 #>  2 A16X5FB3HAFCKN    30            26 #>  3 A1E9D1OT9VJYDZ    40            25 #>  4 A16FPOYD7566WI    35            38 #>  5 A11NOTVHWST7Y3    26            25 #>  6 A3TDR6MXS6UO5Z    33            28 #>  7 A3OD4F0SA7EBCL    33            57 #>  8 A123PBQDU71I5O    30            32 #>  9 A25NGIY591U3DK    48            25 #> 10 A11WCFPJSR5VZP    33            43

title: Data Blinding with vazul
text: scramble_variables() function scrambles values specified columns data frame. data: data frame cols: Columns scramble (supports tidyselect helpers) together: TRUE, variables scrambled together unit per row; FALSE (default), variable scrambled independently .groups: Optional grouping columns within-group scrambling column scrambled independently: Notice x y scrambled independently . together = TRUE, selected columns scrambled unit, preserving row-level relationships: Notice pairs (1, “”), (2, “b”), etc., remain intact assigned different rows. Use .groups parameter scramble within groups: Values x swapped within original group (B). can combine parameters:
code: df <- data.frame(   x = 1:6,   y = letters[1:6],   group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B") )  set.seed(123) scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y")) #>   x y group #> 1 3 e     A #> 2 6 d     A #> 3 2 b     A #> 4 4 f     B #> 5 5 a     B #> 6 1 c     B set.seed(456) scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y"), together = TRUE) #>   x y group #> 1 5 e     A #> 2 6 f     A #> 3 3 c     A #> 4 2 b     B #> 5 1 a     B #> 6 4 d     B set.seed(1) scramble_variables(df, "x", .groups = "group") #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     1 a     A     #> 2     2 b     A     #> 3     3 c     A     #> 4     4 d     B     #> 5     5 e     B     #> 6     6 f     B set.seed(100) scramble_variables(df, c("x", "y"), .groups = "group", together = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     2 b     A     #> 2     1 a     A     #> 3     3 c     A     #> 4     6 f     B     #> 5     4 d     B     #> 6     5 e     B data(williams)  # Scramble age and ecology within gender groups set.seed(42) williams_scrambled <- williams |>   scramble_variables(c("age", "ecology"), .groups = "gender")  # Check that values are preserved within groups williams |>   group_by(gender) |>   summarise(mean_age = mean(age, na.rm = TRUE)) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   gender mean_age #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1      1     33.8 #> 2      2     34.6  williams_scrambled |>   group_by(gender) |>   summarise(mean_age = mean(age, na.rm = TRUE)) #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   gender mean_age #>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1      1     33.8 #> 2      2     34.6

text: scramble_variables_rowwise() function scrambles values within row across specified columns. useful scrambling repeated measures item responses. data: data frame ...: Column sets scramble (supports tidyselect helpers) Within row, values shuffled among item columns. can scramble multiple sets columns independently:
code: df <- data.frame(   item1 = c(1, 4, 7),   item2 = c(2, 5, 8),   item3 = c(3, 6, 9),   id = 1:3 )  set.seed(123) result <- scramble_variables_rowwise(df, c("item1", "item2", "item3")) result #>   item1 item2 item3 id #> 1     3     1     2  1 #> 2     5     4     6  2 #> 3     8     9     7  3 df2 <- data.frame(   day_1 = c(1, 4, 7),   day_2 = c(2, 5, 8),   day_3 = c(3, 6, 9),   score_a = c(10, 40, 70),   score_b = c(20, 50, 80),   id = 1:3 )  set.seed(1) result2 <- scramble_variables_rowwise(   df2,   starts_with("day_"),   c("score_a", "score_b") ) result2 #>   day_1 day_2 day_3 score_a score_b id #> 1     1     2     3      20      10  1 #> 2     4     5     6      40      50  2 #> 3     9     7     8      70      80  3

title: Data Blinding with vazul
text: vazul package includes two research datasets demonstration practice. Many Analysts Religion Project (MARP) dataset contains 10,535 participants 24 countries: Williams study dataset contains 112 participants stereotyping study:
code: data(marp) dim(marp) #> [1] 10535    46  # Example: Scramble religiosity scores within countries set.seed(42) marp_blinded <- marp |>   scramble_variables(starts_with("rel_"), .groups = "country")  # Original and scrambled have same country-level means original_means <- marp |>   group_by(country) |>   summarise(rel_1_mean = mean(rel_1, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  scrambled_means <- marp_blinded |>   group_by(country) |>   summarise(rel_1_mean = mean(rel_1, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")  all.equal(original_means$rel_1_mean, scrambled_means$rel_1_mean) #> [1] "Mean relative difference: 0.2219757" data(williams) dim(williams) #> [1] 112  25  # Example: Mask the ecology condition for blind analysis set.seed(42) williams_blinded <- williams |>   mask_variables("ecology")  # Analysts can work with masked conditions williams_blinded |>   group_by(ecology) |>   summarise(     n = n(),     mean_impulsivity = mean(Impuls_1, na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   ecology              n mean_impulsivity #>   <chr>            <int>            <dbl> #> 1 ecology_group_01    56             4.32 #> 2 ecology_group_02    56             4.61

title: vazul
text: vazul R package data blinding research contexts. offers two main approaches anonymize data preserving analytical validity: masking (replacing values anonymous labels) scrambling (randomizing order existing values).

title: vazul
text: Masking replaces original values anonymous labels, completely hiding original information: Scrambling preserves original values randomizes order:
code: treatment <- c("control", "treatment", "control") mask_labels(treatment) #> "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02" "masked_group_01" scramble_values(treatment)  #> "treatment" "control" "control"  # Same values, different order

title: vazul
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("nthun/vazul")

title: vazul
text: Replace categorical values anonymous labels completely hide original information.

title: vazul
code: library(vazul)  # Basic masking treatment <- c("control", "treatment", "control", "treatment") set.seed(123) mask_labels(treatment) #> "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02" "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02"  # Custom prefix mask_labels(treatment, prefix = "group_") #> "group_01" "group_02" "group_01" "group_02"

title: vazul
code: df <- data.frame(   condition = c("A", "B", "A", "B"),   treatment = c("ctrl", "test", "ctrl", "test"),   score = c(85, 92, 78, 88) )  # Mask multiple columns mask_variables(df, c("condition", "treatment"))  # Use tidyselect helpers mask_variables(df, where(is.character))

title: vazul
code: # Consistent masking across rows for categorical data df |> mask_variables_rowwise(c("condition", "treatment"))

title: vazul
text: Randomize order values preserving original data content.

title: vazul
code: # Numeric data set.seed(123)  scramble_values(1:5) #> [1] 3 2 5 4 1  # Categorical data scramble_values(c("A", "B", "C", "A", "B")) #> [1] "B" "A" "C" "B" "A"

title: vazul
code: df <- data.frame(x = 1:6, group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 3))  # Scramble across entire column scramble_variables(df, "x")  # Scramble within groups scramble_variables(df, "x", .groups = "group")  # Using dplyr grouping library(dplyr) df |> group_by(group) |> scramble_variables("x")

title: vazul

code: # Example with character vector set.seed(123) treatment <- c("control", "treatment", "control", "treatment") mask_labels(treatment) #>           control         treatment           control         treatment  #> "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02" "masked_group_01" "masked_group_02"   # Example with custom prefix set.seed(456) condition <- c("A", "B", "C", "A", "B", "C") mask_labels(condition, prefix = "group_") #>          A          B          C          A          B          C  #> "group_01" "group_03" "group_02" "group_01" "group_03" "group_02"   # Example with factor vector set.seed(789) ecology <- factor(c("Desperate", "Hopeful", "Desperate", "Hopeful")) mask_labels(ecology) #>       Desperate         Hopeful       Desperate         Hopeful  #> masked_group_01 masked_group_02 masked_group_01 masked_group_02  #> Levels: masked_group_01 masked_group_02  # Using with dataset column data(williams) set.seed(123) williams$ecology_masked <- mask_labels(williams$ecology) head(williams[c("ecology", "ecology_masked")]) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   ecology   ecology_masked  #>   <chr>     <chr>           #> 1 Hopeful   masked_group_01 #> 2 Desperate masked_group_02 #> 3 Desperate masked_group_02 #> 4 Hopeful   masked_group_01 #> 5 Desperate masked_group_02 #> 6 Desperate masked_group_02

code: df <- data.frame(   treat_1 = c(1, 2, 3),   treat_2 = c(4, 5, 6),   outcome_a = c(7, 8, 9),   outcome_b = c(10, 11, 12),   id = 1:3 )  # Mask two variable sets with default prefixes title: Mask categorical variables with random labels in a data frame — mask_variables
code: mask_variables(data, ..., across_variables = FALSE)

title: Mask categorical variables with random labels in a data frame — mask_variables
text: data data frame ... Columns mask. can : tidyselect expression (e.g., starts_with("treat_")) character vector column names (e.g., c("var1", "var2")) Multiple sets can provided separate arguments character factor columns processed. across_variables logical. TRUE, selected variables use set masked labels. FALSE (default), variable gets independent set masked labels using column name prefix.

title: Mask categorical variables with random labels in a data frame — mask_variables
text: data frame specified categorical columns masked. character factor columns can processed.

title: Mask categorical variables with random labels in a data frame — mask_variables
code: # Create example data df <- data.frame(   treatment = c("control", "intervention", "control"),   outcome = c("success", "failure", "success"),   score = c(1, 2, 3)  # numeric, won't be masked )  set.seed(123) # Independent masking for each variable (default - uses column names as # prefixes) mask_variables(df, c("treatment", "outcome")) #>            treatment          outcome score #> 1 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01     1 #> 2 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_02     2 #> 3 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01     3  set.seed(456) # Shared masking across variables mask_variables(df, c("treatment", "outcome"), across_variables = TRUE) #>         treatment         outcome score #> 1 masked_group_01 masked_group_03     1 #> 2 masked_group_04 masked_group_02     2 #> 3 masked_group_01 masked_group_03     3  # Using tidyselect helpers mask_variables(df, where(is.character)) #>            treatment          outcome score #> 1 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01     1 #> 2 treatment_group_02 outcome_group_02     2 #> 3 treatment_group_01 outcome_group_01     3  # Example with multiple categorical columns df2 <- data.frame(   group = c("A", "B", "A", "B"),   condition = c("ctrl", "test", "ctrl", "test") ) set.seed(123) result <- mask_variables(df2, c("group", "condition")) print(result) #>            group          condition #> 1 group_group_01 condition_group_01 #> 2 group_group_02 condition_group_02 #> 3 group_group_01 condition_group_01 #> 4 group_group_02 condition_group_02  # Example with williams dataset (multiple categorical columns) data(williams) set.seed(456) williams_masked <- mask_variables(williams, c("subject", "ecology")) head(williams_masked[c("subject", "ecology")]) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   subject           ecology          #>   <chr>             <chr>            #> 1 subject_group_109 ecology_group_02 #> 2 subject_group_101 ecology_group_01 #> 3 subject_group_035 ecology_group_01 #> 4 subject_group_038 ecology_group_02 #> 5 subject_group_085 ecology_group_01 #> 6 subject_group_027 ecology_group_01

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: data data frame cols Columns scramble. Accepts column names, positions, tidyselect helpers like starts_with(), contains(), (), etc. .groups Optional grouping columns. Scrambling done within group. Supports tidyselect syntax cols. together logical. TRUE, variables scrambled together unit per row. Values across different variables kept intact assigned different rows. FALSE (default), variable scrambled independently.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
text: data frame specified columns scrambled. grouping specified, scrambling done within group.

title: Scrambling the content of several variables in a data frame — scramble_variables
code: df <- data.frame(x = 1:6, y = letters[1:6], group = c("A", "A", "A", "B", "B", "B"))  set.seed(123) # Example without grouping. Variables scrambled across the entire data frame. df |> scramble_variables(c("x", "y")) #>   x y group #> 1 3 e     A #> 2 6 d     A #> 3 2 b     A #> 4 4 f     B #> 5 5 a     B #> 6 1 c     B  # Example with together = TRUE. Variables scrambled together as a unit per row. df |> scramble_variables(c("x", "y"), together = TRUE) #>   x y group #> 1 3 c     A #> 2 5 e     A #> 3 6 f     A #> 4 4 d     B #> 5 1 a     B #> 6 2 b     B  # Example with grouping. Variable only scrambled within groups. df |> scramble_variables("y", .groups = "group") #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     1 a     A     #> 2     2 c     A     #> 3     3 b     A     #> 4     4 f     B     #> 5     5 e     B     #> 6     6 d     B      # Example combining grouping and together parameters df |> scramble_variables(c("x", "y"), .groups = "group", together = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     3 c     A     #> 2     2 b     A     #> 3     1 a     A     #> 4     5 e     B     #> 5     4 d     B     #> 6     6 f     B      # Example with tidyselect helpers library(dplyr) df |> scramble_variables(starts_with("x")) #>   x y group #> 1 6 a     A #> 2 1 b     A #> 3 3 c     A #> 4 4 d     B #> 5 5 e     B #> 6 2 f     B df |> scramble_variables(where(is.numeric), .groups = "group") #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>       x y     group #>   <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1     3 a     A     #> 2     2 b     A     #> 3     1 c     A     #> 4     4 d     B     #> 5     6 e     B     #> 6     5 f     B      # Example with the 'williams' dataset if (requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(williams, package = "vazul")   williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"))   williams |> scramble_variables(1:5)   williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"), .groups = "gender")   williams |> scramble_variables(c(1, 2), .groups = c(3))   williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"), together = TRUE)   williams |> scramble_variables(c("ecology", "age"), .groups = "gender", together = TRUE) } #> # A tibble: 112 × 25 #>    subject   SexUnres_1 SexUnres_2 SexUnres_3 SexUnres_4_r SexUnres_5_r Impuls_1 #>    <chr>          <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 A30MP4LX…          5          3          2            3            2        3 #>  2 A16X5FB3…          7          7          7            4            2        6 #>  3 A1E9D1OT…          2          4          6            3            3        3 #>  4 A16FPOYD…          5          4          5            3            3        4 #>  5 A11NOTVH…          5          5          6            3            3        5 #>  6 A3TDR6MX…          5          6          6            3            2        5 #>  7 A3OD4F0S…          5          6          5            3            4        5 #>  8 A123PBQD…          4          6          5            2            3        6 #>  9 A25NGIY5…          6          5          6            3            2        6 #> 10 A11WCFPJ…          4          4          4            1            1        1 #> # ℹ 102 more rows #> # ℹ 18 more variables: Impuls_2_r <dbl>, Impul_3_r <dbl>, Opport_1 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_2 <dbl>, Opport_3 <dbl>, Opport_4 <dbl>, Opport_5 <dbl>, #> #   Opport_6_r <dbl>, InvEdu_1_r <dbl>, InvEdu_2_r <dbl>, InvChild_1 <dbl>, #> # what: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
text: Data study Williams et al. testing whether high-wealth individuals perceived faster life history strategies (e.g., impulsive, less invested) associated "desperate" ecological conditions compared "hopeful" ones.

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
code: data(williams)

title: Stereotyping of High-Wealth Individuals Across Ecologies — williams
text: data frame 224 rows (one per participant) 25 variables: subject Unique subject identifier (integer). ecology Experimental condition: "Desperate" "Hopeful" (character). age Participant's age years (numeric). gender Self-reported gender: 1 = Male, 2 = Female (numeric); may recoded factor. duration_in_seconds Time taken complete survey (numeric). attention_1 First attention check response: 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect (numeric). attention_2 Second attention check response: 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect (numeric). SexUnres_1 Perceived sexual unrestrictedness: "likely short-term relationships" (1–7 Likert). SexUnres_2 "likely engage casual sex" (1–7). SexUnres_3 "interested long-term commitment" (1–7). SexUnres_4_r "faithful romantic partners" — reverse-coded (1–7). SexUnres_5_r "committed relationships" — reverse-coded (1–7). Impuls_1 "acts without thinking" (1–7). Impuls_2_r "thinks carefully acting" — reverse-coded (1–7). Impul_3_r "plans ahead" — reverse-coded (1–7). Opport_1 "opportunities long-term planning exist" (1–7). Opport_2 "can save money future" (1–7). Opport_3 "can make career plans" (1–7). Opport_4 "can plan retirement" (1–7). Opport_5 "control future outcomes" (1–7). Opport_6_r "life unpredictable" — reverse-coded (1–7). InvEdu_1_r "invests education" — reverse-coded (1–7). InvEdu_2_r "values academic achievement" — reverse-coded (1–7). InvChild_1 "invests time resources children" (1–7). InvChild_2_r "neglects parental responsibilities" — reverse-coded (1–7).
